message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is leiomyoma, which is a type of benign uterine tumor that can cause heavy bleeding and abdominal pain. Endometrial hyperplasia would show abnormal growth of cells in the endometrium, which is not visible in the photomicrograph. Endometriosis would not cause an enlarged uterus. Adenomyosis would show endometrial cells within the myometrium, which is not visible in the photomicrograph.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of heavy bleeding and an enlarged, nodular uterus suggest a leiomyoma, which is a benign smooth muscle tumor of the uterus. Endometrial hyperplasia typically presents with abnormal uterine bleeding but usually does not cause an enlarged uterus. Endometriosis presents with dysmenorrhea but typically does not cause an enlarged uterus. Adenomyosis can cause an enlarged uterus but typically presents with dysmenorrhea rather than heavy bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus, which suggests leiomyoma. Endometrial hyperplasia would typically be associated with abnormal endometrial thickening and abnormal bleeding. Endometriosis would be associated with dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia but not necessarily an enlarged uterus. Adenomyosis typically presents with heavy and prolonged bleeding but not necessarily nodularity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is leiomyoma, or uterine fibroid. The nodular uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation, heavy bleeding with menstruation, and dyspareunia are typical characteristics of leiomyoma. Adenomyosis would cause a diffusely enlarged uterus, and endometriosis would not cause uterine enlargement. Endometrial hyperplasia can also cause heavy bleeding but is not consistent with the findings of an enlarged uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the enlarged, nodular uterus, suggest the most likely diagnosis is leiomyoma (also known as uterine fibroids). Endometrial hyperplasia would show abnormal growth of the endometrial tissue in the uterus, but size changes would not be seen. Endometriosis would not cause an enlarged uterus. Adenomyosis would show an enlarged and boggy uterus but not nodular.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The enlarged, nodular uterus and history of heavy bleeding with normal flow suggest Leiomyoma, which is a benign smooth muscle tumor of the uterus. Endometrial hyperplasia may also cause heavy bleeding but the enlarged uterus is not typical. Endometriosis and adenomyosis may cause dyspareunia and cyclical abdominal pain, but they do not typically cause an enlarged uterus. The photomicrograph is not necessary to make the diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as heavy bleeding, dyspareunia, and cyclical abdominal pain, are suggestive of leiomyoma. The enlarged nodular uterus also supports this diagnosis. Endometrial hyperplasia presents with abnormal bleeding but the uterus is normal in size. Endometriosis and adenomyosis can also cause pain and heavy bleeding, but the enlarged uterus points more towards leiomyoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination suggest a leiomyoma (fibroid). The photomicrograph would confirm this diagnosis as it would show a benign smooth muscle tumor with no regard for the endometrial cycle. Endometrial hyperplasia, endometriosis, and adenomyosis do not usually cause an enlarged nodular uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest a leiomyoma, which is a common benign tumor of the uterus that can cause heavy bleeding and abdominal pain. Endometrial hyperplasia is a precursor to endometrial cancer and is not consistent with a nodular uterus. Endometriosis typically presents as dysmenorrhea and infertility, and the uterus is usually not asymmetrically enlarged. Adenomyosis would show endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, which is not seen on the photomicrograph.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy bleeding with menstruation, dyspareunia, and cyclical abdominal pain suggests a uterine leiomyoma. The asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus further supports this diagnosis. Endometrial hyperplasia and adenomyosis can cause abnormal bleeding but do not typically cause an enlarged uterus. Endometriosis may cause dyspareunia and abdominal pain but does not typically cause heavy bleeding.
